Triggering Event:
"I'm sitting here on this godforsaken Friday night, staring at my cold dinner plate like it's some kinda fucking abstract art. Alone again, just me and the echo of my own breathing in this too-silent house. I've been widowed for what feels like a bloody century now, but you'd think I'd be used to this lonesome shit by now.

I was supposed to meet up with some old work pals tonight - we were gonna grab dinner, laugh about the good ol' days at TechCorp, maybe even reminisce about how we used to pull all-nighters coding like our lives depended on it. But nope, they all had 'other plans'. Can't blame them, I guess. It's not like they've got a damn widow card to play.

So here I am, just another Friday night in the life of a 51-year-old software engineer who's still trying to figure out how to code her way through this fucking void called loneliness."
Generated Assessment:
"Are you bloody kidding me? Tonight's a total loss. I mean, what's the point of even having friends if they're just gonna bail on you when things get tough? They're either gonna show up and make everything okay, or they're gonna leave me hanging like the pathetic excuse for a human being I am.

I swear, it's like they don't know how to deal with real emotions. Real pain. Real heartache. You can't just 'have other plans' when someone's lost their partner of 25 years. That's not something you can just 'get over' or'move on' from. It's like they're saying, 'Sorry, buddy, but your feelings aren't valid.'

And don't even get me started on the dinner plans. Who needs social interaction anyway? I'll just stick to eating alone in front of the TV, watching reruns of The Office until I forget what it's like to have actual human connection. At least then I won't feel like a complete waste of space.

It's not like I'm asking for much. Just a few hours of conversation, some decent company... is that really too much to ask? Apparently so. So yeah, tonight's a total write-off. Might as well just stay home and drink myself into oblivion."<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Fucking hell, it's Monday again," she muttered, slamming her car door shut. The school loomed ahead like an ominous monolith, its once vibrant colors now dull under the gray sky. She'd woken up to another empty bed, another silent apartment, and another goddamn reminder that her life was a endless cycle of lessons plans, parent-teacher conferences, and correction marks.

As she trudged through the crowded hallway, kids laughing, hugging, sharing stories from their weekend, she felt like an intruder. They had lives outside this place, something she couldn't remember having in years. She passed by the poster boards decorating the walls, each one a testament to someone else's family, someone else's happiness.

"Miss Thompson!" a kid called out, waving at her from the science lab. She forced a smile, her heart heavy like concrete. "Hey, Jake. Ready for another exciting week of chemistry?"

Christ, even her sarcasm sounded tired. She sighed internally, pushing open the door to her classroom. Another week, another fucking Monday.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why do I always get stuck with the worst classes? Chemistry, of all things. Who thought that was a good idea? It's not like anyone actually understands the material anyway. Just a bunch of memorization nonsense.

And don't even get me started on the students. So clueless, so entitled. Like they're the ones who have to deal with the stress of teaching all day. I swear, some of them think they know more than I do just because they can Google something.

But what really gets my blood boiling is when they try to make small talk. "Oh, Miss Thompson, how was your weekend?" Um, it was fine, thanks for asking. Not exactly the highlight of my year. But hey, let's pretend like I'm some kind of functioning member of society.

I glance around the room, taking in the sea of blank faces. No one cares about my weekend, no one cares about anything except themselves. And I'm just here to spoon-feed them information until they can barely remember their own names.

Why do I bother? It's not like anyone appreciates me. I'm just a cog in the machine, a replaceable part. My life is just a never-ending cycle of drudgery, and I'm just going through the motions.

The bell rings, signaling the start of class. Great, just what I needed. More monotony. I force a weak smile onto my face, trying to muster up some enthusiasm for the next hour of torture.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Great, just freaking peachy! I wake up this morning, my hands already twitching for the brush, ready to dance with the canvas like old times. But no, not today, jackass brain says. Today's the day my 'artistic temperament' decides to throw a hissy fit. My heart's pounding like a kick drum at some godforsaken rave, and my palms are slicker than an ice rink in August. Why? Because Mrs. Thompson next door just invited us over for dinner tomorrow night. Big deal, right? Wrong! It's not the dinner that's got me in knots, it's her husband, Bob. That man could make a statue of David feel underdressed with his endless innuendos and 'jokes'. I mean, come on! I'm an artist, not a comedian. And now my wife, bless her heart, she's all 'Oh, it'll be fine, we just need to loosen up a bit, try some new things.' Loosen up? Loosen up?! I'd love to loosen up, maybe start with that noose around my neck if this anxiety keeps up. But no, instead of throttling Bob and his bad jokes, I'm here, pacing like a caged tiger, trying to figure out how to paint a smile on my face for tomorrow night. Because God forbid we offend the neighbors. Oh, the irony! Me, an artist, offending people with my mere existence. Typical."
Generated Assessment:
The impending dinner engagement has precipitated a maelstrom within my cerebral cortex. The mere thought of Mrs. Thompson's husband, Bob, sets off a chain reaction of trepidation, as if the very fabric of our social dynamics hangs precariously in the balance. His propensity for cringe-worthy humor and calculated wit has created an aura of tension, which I am inexplicably compelled to internalize.

It is nothing short of astonishing that my wife would suggest I "loosen up" and attempt to navigate this minefield with aplomb. Does she not comprehend the gravity of the situation? The weight of expectation, the crushing pressure to conform to societal norms, all bearing down upon me like an unyielding behemoth.

And yet, I am expected to don a mask of joviality, to feign interest in Bob's vacuous remarks and awkward silences. The very notion is an affront to my artistic sensibilities, a travesty of sorts. How can I possibly reconcile my creative essence with the stifling conventions of polite society?

As I pace back and forth, my mind racing with worst-case scenarios, I am struck by the cruel irony of it all. A dinner party, ostensibly a celebration of community and camaraderie, has morphed into a battleground where I must confront the abyssal void of my own inadequacy. The stakes are high, and I fear that one misstep will spell disaster – not for my marriage, but for my very soul.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile confines of Ward C, Nurse Matthew tended to Mrs. Harrington's bedpan, his lips pressed into a thin line, concealing the turmoil within. The elderly woman had complained about his care all morning, her voice shrill and relentless as a drill boring into his skull. He completed his task mechanically, each movement precise and deliberate.

Suddenly, Mrs. Harrington grabbed his wrist with surprising strength. "You're not listening to me!" she screeched. Matthew froze, then slowly looked at her hand, his eyes hardening like ice. "Release my arm," he commanded, his voice dangerously quiet.

She ignored him, digging her nails into his skin. "I deserve better than this! I'm a paying customer!"

A red haze descended over Matthew's vision. He felt the familiar heat of rage coursing through his veins, threatening to consume him. But he held it back, pushing down on the lid of Pandora's box with every ounce of willpower.

"Madam," he said, enunciating each syllable with chilling clarity, "I will tolerate no further abuse from you or anyone else." He pried her fingers off his wrist, one by one, until she was forced to let go. Then he straightened up, towering over her, his gaze unblinking.

"Remember this moment," he said, his voice barely above a whisper but resonating like thunder in the silent ward. "For if you dare lay another hand on me or any of my colleagues, I promise you, we will not be so civil again." With that, he turned on his heel and walked away, leaving Mrs. Harrington staring after him, her face pale with shock.

Matthew's hands trembled as he washed them at the sink, the water running red with his blood from where she'd broken skin. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for the rest of his shift. But inside, the rage boiled on, waiting for another spark to ignite it into an inferno.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, that old lady was totally out of control today. She came at me with those claws out, like I was some kind of monster. I mean, what's wrong with her? Can't even treat her own body with respect. And now she's going around spreading rumors about how I treated her. Like I'm some kind of monster just because she got a little upset.

I swear, some people have no idea how to behave themselves. They think they can just do whatever they want and nobody will call them out on it. Newsflash: someone always calls you out. And when they do, you'd better be ready.

I've been working with patients who are way more challenging than Mrs. Harrington. At least she's consistent. You never know what's going to set her off next. But still, I shouldn't have to deal with that kind of disrespect. It's not like I'm asking for much.

And don't even get me started on the other nurses who were too afraid to stand up to her. What's wrong with them? Don't they know that if you let people walk all over you, they'll just keep doing it? I'm not going to let that happen on my watch.

I'm just glad I was able to hold my ground. If she had kept pushing, I might have lost my cool. But I didn't. I kept my composure and showed her who's boss. That's what I do. And if she can't handle that, well, that's not my problem.

It's funny, though - sometimes I wonder if some people are just born to be difficult. Like, maybe Mrs. Harrington has some kind of special talent for driving people crazy. Whatever it is, I'm not buying it. I'm just here to do my job and make sure everyone gets the care they need. Not to indulge some kind of personal vendetta against me.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Oh God, oh God, okay, focus... It's 3 AM, can't sleep again. Lab results are due tomorrow, and I've been staring at these goddamn numbers for hours. They're all wrong, they have to be. My hands won't stop shaking, like they're trying to tell me something.

I swear I double-checked the samples, but what if I missed something? What if my mind's playing tricks again? I can feel it, that tightness in my chest, like a vice squeezing my heart. It's happening, isn't it? The panic, creeping up my spine like icy fingers.

Christ, the room's spinning. Is that the fan or is it me? I need to move, do something. I stumble out of bed, knocking over empty coffee cups. They crash onto the floor, but I can't stop now. I have to check, again and again, until it makes sense.

I'm back at my desk, fingers flying over the keyboard, eyes glued to the screen. The numbers blur, jump around like they're alive. I rub my temples, trying to make them stay still. It's no use. I can't think, can't breathe.

Suddenly, the smoke detector goes off. Just a false alarm, but it's enough to send me spiraling. My heart's pounding like a drum in my ears. I'm suffocating, drowning right here in my goddamn apartment. I need air. I need out.

I grab my coat, rush outside, and collapse onto the wet grass. Rain's pouring down now, washing over me, but it doesn't matter. Nothing matters except this fucking panic, clutching at me like a monster from the depths.

I'm gonna lose it, aren't I? All because of some stupid numbers. My career, my life... everything's falling apart. And there's nothing, nothing I can do to stop it.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a failure. I mean, look at me, always freaking out about stupid stuff. Like, I'll be driving, and suddenly I'm convinced the car's going to explode. Never mind the fact that it's just a minor fender bender. Nope, I'm a ticking time bomb, just waiting to go off.

And don't even get me started on math. I swear, every time I try to do a simple calculation, my brain turns into mush. Whole numbers, fractions, decimals – it's all just gibberish to me. I'm basically useless when it comes to numbers.

But hey, at least I'm consistent, right? Always getting anxious, always losing my cool. That's just who I am. A hot mess, through and through. And it's not like I'm the only one, either. Everyone else must be feeling the same way, right?

I mean, have you ever noticed how everyone else seems so calm and collected? Never panicking, never freaking out. But no, I'm the one who's always on edge, always ready to blow. It's like I'm some kind of freak, or something.

And it's not just math or driving or anything like that. No, I'm a total disaster in every aspect of my life. My relationships are doomed, my job is a joke, and my health is shot. Entirely my fault, of course. I'm just a magnet for bad luck.

So yeah, that's me in a nutshell. A walking, talking disaster waiting to happen. Joy.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Sure thing, mate. So picture this, it's Saturday night and you're in the kitchen, your domain, your sanctuary. You've been at it all day, prepping for the dinner rush that never came. The restaurant's empty, like a ghost town, and your partner, they canceled their plans with you last minute to catch up with some old mates from uni.

You're there, alone, surrounded by all this food, but feeling pretty hollow yourself. You start chopping onions, tears streaming down your face, and you think, "Well, at least I'm not crying over the fact that I'm crying over an onion." Sarcasm, thy name is chef's life.

You plate up the dish you've been working on all day, a real showstopper, and snap a pic. "Might as well make it Instagram-worthy," you think, "Maybe they'll see what they're missing out on." You caption it something like, "When your Saturday night plans are better than theirs 😢🍴"

As you're cleaning up, you notice a missed call from them. They left a voicemail, probably to apologize, but you're not really in the mood for words right now. So, you put on some tunes, crank up the volume, and let the music do the talking for both of you.

You take a deep breath, look around at the kitchen that's seen better days, and think, "Here's to another solitary Saturday night, chef." And you raise your (clean) knife like it's a glass, toasting yourself in this big empty restaurant. Cheers to that, huh?
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why did they have to cancel on me? Like, I get it, they're busy, but can't they just give me a heads up? I swear, I was looking forward to spending the evening with them, and now I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but my thoughts and a bunch of mediocre food.

And don't even get me started on the state of this kitchen. It's like a disaster zone in here! I mean, I know I've been slaving away all day, but seriously, who needs that much clutter? It's like they expect me to cook for a crowd or something. Newsflash: I'm a one-person team, not a miracle worker!

But hey, at least I got to vent about how crappy my night is going to be on social media. That's gotta count for something, right? I mean, who doesn't love a good rant about how their significant other bailed on them? It's not like I'm bitter or anything... oh wait, I totally am.

And now I'm stuck listening to music to drown out the sound of my own disappointment. Like, I'm basically a professional at wallowing in self-pity. Who needs therapy when you've got Spotify, am I right?

I guess I'll just have to toast myself to a miserable solo Saturday night. Because, hey, at least I'm not completely alone in this mess. There's always the kitchen, right? Where the only audience I need is the one I created – the ghost of my own despair.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Event Scenario:**

*59-year-old scientist, Harry, was hunched over his cluttered desk in the dimly lit home office he'd converted from their guest room. His eyes, bloodshot and weary, were glued to his laptop screen, squinting at the complex formulas and graphs that refused to align.*

*"Damn it!"* *he snapped, slamming his fist on the wooden surface. The monitor flickered but held firm. His wife, Linda, poked her head in from the hallway, concern etched on her face.*

*"Harry, it's late. You've been at this for hours. Why don't you take a break?"*

*Harry didn't respond, just ran his hands through his thinning hair, disheveling what was left of his comb-over. He felt the familiar tightness in his chest, the suffocating anxiety that had become his constant companion.*

*"I can't,"* *he muttered, turning back to the screen. "Not until I figure this out. The grant's on the line. Our future's on the line."*

*Linda stepped into the room, placing a hand on his shoulder. He shrugged it off, gentler than he wanted.*

*"Harry, we've been through this. You can't keep pushing yourself like this. You're not invincible."*

*Harry spun around, his face contorted with anger and fear.*

*"Don't you think I know that?"* *he growled. "I'm 59, Linda! I should be at the peak of my career, not scrambling for scraps like some fledgling researcher. We're drowning in debt, and if I can't secure this grant..."*

*His voice cracked, and he looked away, blinking back tears. Linda sighed, sitting down beside him.*

*"We'll figure something out,"* *she said softly. "Together."*

*Harry just shook his head, turning back to the screen. He knew better than anyone that some things were beyond figuring out.*
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a failure. Can't even get this one right. I mean, who needs sleep when there's science to be done? My whole life has been leading up to this moment - securing that grant, proving myself. And now, it's slipping away from me. 

I swear, Linda doesn't understand. She thinks she does, but she's just not seeing the big picture. I'm not just doing this for us; I'm doing it for my legacy. For all those years of hard work, all those late nights and early mornings... it's all worth it, right?

But no, instead of supporting me, she's always questioning my abilities. "You're not invincible," she says. Like, what does she know? She's never put herself in my shoes. I've sacrificed so much for this research, for our family... 

And another thing, why do I always have to be the one to push through? Can't anyone else see how close we are to making a breakthrough? It's like they're just waiting for me to fail so they can swoop in and save the day. Newsflash: I'm the one who's been carrying this load for years.

Linda keeps saying we'll figure something out together, but what does that even mean? Does she really think I'm just going to magically come up with a solution because we're holding hands? Please. This isn't some fairy tale romance; it's science. And in science, results speak louder than feelings.

I guess what really gets under my skin is that everyone expects me to succeed. The colleagues, the mentors, the funding committee... they all think I should be able to pull this off. And maybe I am capable, but sometimes it feels like no one believes in me anymore. Not even Linda.

It's like, I'm 59 years old, for crying out loud! I should be at the top of my game by now. Instead, I'm stuck in this rut, struggling to make ends meet. And it's all because of this one grant. If I don't get it, everything falls apart. That's just the way it is.

Sometimes I wonder if it's all worth it. Is this really what I want to spend my life doing? But then I look at the equations on my screen, and I feel that spark again. That's what drives me, that's what makes me tick. So, yeah, I'll keep pushing forward, no matter what. Because that's what winners do.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Fuck me, today was supposed to be my day off, but that asshole Dr. Thompson called in sick. Again. So here I am, stuck on this goddamn floor, dealing with Mrs. Henderson's constant fucking complaining about her 'excruciating' pain. Bitch please, it's just a sprain.

And then, oh joy, Mr. Jenkins' family walks in, all smiles and laughter, like they're at a fucking picnic. I see him there, his hand resting on that little bitch of a nurse he's been fucking behind my back. They didn't even have the decency to look guilty, just sneered at me like I'm some pathetic whore who can't keep her man.

I wanted to scream, to rip out their throats with my bare hands. But all I did was stand there, frozen, while they fucking laughed at me. Shit, even the patients were staring, whispering behind their hands about the nurse who couldn't hold onto her man.

Fuck them all. Fuck this job, fuck that cheating bastard, and fuck my life. I'm so goddamn tired of feeling like a fucking failure."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, today was literally the worst. My day started off okay, I guess. I got to the hospital early, ready to tackle whatever came my way. But then I saw Dr. Thompson's name on the schedule and my heart sank. Like, what's the point of even having a day off if someone else is just going to swoop in and steal the show?

I swear, that guy has no idea how much stress he causes me. He's always calling in at the last minute, leaving me to deal with the fallout. And now, here I am, stuck with Mrs. Henderson's drama. She's always complaining about something, and today was no exception. Her pain is just so...excruciating. I feel bad for her, but honestly, it's getting old.

Just as I thought things couldn't get any worse, Mr. Jenkins' family walked in. They looked so happy, laughing and smiling like they were on vacation or something. And then I saw him - standing right next to his wife, his hand casually resting on hers. It was like they were trying to rub it in my face or something.

I tried to play it cool, but inside I was seething. How could he do that to me? Doesn't he know I'm still hurting over our breakup? The way he just smiled and waved at me, like we were friends or something...it was infuriating.

I felt like screaming, but I just stood there, frozen. The patients were staring, whispering behind their hands, and I knew everyone was talking about me. That nurse, in particular, seemed to think she was better than me just because she had Mr. Jenkins wrapped around her finger.

It's days like these that make me wonder why I even bother coming to work. Maybe I'm just not cut out for this whole nursing thing. Maybe I'm just too sensitive, too emotional. Whatever it is, it feels like the world is just conspiring against me today.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of her study, where the hum of servers was once a symphony of accomplishment, now it merely underscored the emptiness she felt. Her fingers, gnarled by age and arthritis, hesitated over the keyboard. It had been weeks since she last coded, her mind fogged by an inexplicable melancholy that clung to her like the damp chill of an English autumn.

She had always been a creature of routine, but lately, even the familiar comforts of her work seemed alien. The lines of code, once clear and precise, now blurred before her eyes. She found herself staring at the monitor, watching the cursor blink like a metronome counting down the seconds until she could retreat to bed.

Today was different, though. Today, she had received an email from her former colleague, Thomas. They hadn't spoken in years, not since she retired and he moved on to bigger things. The subject line read: "Remembering Old Times." She opened it with trepidation, expecting a polite inquiry into her well-being or perhaps a request for some long-forgotten favor.

But it was none of these. Instead, Thomas had sent her an attachment - a screenshot of their old project board from the software they'd developed together all those years ago. The names of features and functions seemed to dance off the screen, each one a memory trigger waiting to explode like a firework in her mind's eye.

She clicked on one randomly, "User Authentication Module," and was transported back to the days when she could still touch-type without looking at her hands. She remembered the hours they'd spent arguing over algorithms, the countless cups of coffee consumed while they pored over lines of code that now seemed laughably simple.

But with the memories came the melancholy. It wrapped itself around her heart like a vine, squeezing until she could barely breathe. Thomas was still out there, still coding, still living his life. And here she was, trapped in this house, surrounded by reminders of a past that felt more and more like a dream each day.

She closed the email without replying, turning off her computer with a finality that echoed through the empty room. As she made her way upstairs to bed, she couldn't shake the feeling of being left behind, adrift at sea while everyone else had already reached shore. The house felt colder than ever, and she hugged herself tightly, wishing for something - anything - to chase away this gnawing loneliness.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I just got that email from Thomas today. He's still out there doing his thing, making money, getting recognition... meanwhile, I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but memories to keep me company. Those were good times, don't get me wrong, but they're just that - memories. What's the point of dwelling on the past?

I know I used to love coding, but honestly, it feels so... pointless now. All those hours we spent working on projects, all those late nights... what did it even accomplish? We're just relics of a bygone era, clinging to our outdated skills and obsolete knowledge. I mean, have you seen the state of the industry lately? It's all about AI and machine learning now. Who needs humans when you can just give machines a few lines of code?

And don't even get me started on how Thomas is doing. He's probably off somewhere, sipping champagne and basking in the glory of his success. Meanwhile, I'm over here struggling to make ends meet, wondering if anyone will even notice if I disappear tomorrow.

I tried to respond to him, but what's the use? He'll just ignore me or worse, try to sell me on some new fad or trend. No thanks. I've got better things to do with my time. Like staring at these walls, wondering why I even bothered trying to hold on to something that's clearly slipping away from me.

It's just so... unfair. Why does everything have to change? Can't I just stay frozen in time, reliving the good old days? But no, life has other plans. And mine is just a never-ending cycle of disappointment and disillusionment. Joyless, pointless, and utterly devoid of purpose. Just peachy.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"After fifteen years on the job, you'd think I'd be used to this, but no. Today was just another gem in my sparkling career at BigMart. First off, Mrs. Henderson - yes, that's her real name, she insists - waddles up to me like a pregnant hippo and demands where our 'fancy' paper towels are stashed. I direct her to aisle three, but oh no, not good enough. She huffs and puffs about how the new layout is 'ridiculous' and storms off without so much as a thank you.

Then, just when I think it can't get worse, little Timmy 'I'm-all-grown-up-now' Johnson tries to steal a pack of gum while his mom's browsing through magazines. I catch him red-handed, and he actually has the nerve to roll his eyes at me. Me! The guy who's seen him grow from a chubby-cheeked toddler into this lanky, attitude-filled teen. 'You're not gonna tell my mom, are ya?' he sneers. I just smile sweetly - well, as sweetly as one can when they're fighting the urge to roll their eyes right back - and say, 'Oh, I think she'd love to hear about it.'

And to top off this lovely day, my manager, Bob - who's got all the warmth of a frozen fish stick - informs me that I'm working tomorrow too. 'Company policy,' he drones. As if they're doing me some favor by squeezing every last drop of my time and energy.

So here I am, 53 years old, still slaving away in this fluorescent-lit dungeon, surrounded by folks who think the world owes them a living. And for what? A paycheck that barely covers rent, let alone a decent meal out with my girlfriend. I'm not saying I deserve a medal or anything, but a little respect wouldn't hurt, would it?"
Generated Assessment:
As I trudged into work today, I couldn't help but feel a sense of déjà vu. It's always the same story: incompetent customers, entitled employees, and management breathing down my neck. 

Mrs. Henderson, in particular, takes the cake. Her constant complaints about the store's layout are nothing short of exhausting. I've tried explaining the reasoning behind the changes, but does anyone listen? No, of course not. They just assume I'm some kind of incompetent fool who can't even manage a simple store layout.

And don't even get me started on Timmy Johnson. His behavior is a perfect example of why we need stricter supervision. If I hadn't caught him trying to steal, who knows what kind of trouble he might have gotten himself into? His parents seem completely oblivious to his antics, and it's clear they're enabling his bad behavior.

My manager, Bob, is no better. He's always talking about company policy, but what about employee welfare? Does he ever stop to consider how his actions affect us on the ground? I doubt it. He's more concerned with meeting quotas and crushing spirits than actually helping us succeed.

It's days like today that make me wonder why I bother coming to work at all. Is it really worth sacrificing my sanity and self-respect for a paycheck that barely covers my expenses? I suppose it's not my decision, anyway. After all, someone has to keep the wheels of commerce turning, even if it means tolerating subpar treatment from those above me.<|eot_id|>
